▲ Researchers from the University of Dayton Research Institute and the Air Force Research Laboratory are using ALCF supercomputers to shed light on the complex thermal environment that hypersonic vehicles encounter. This image shows the contour of gas velocity along an experimental test article. Image: ALCF Visualization and Data Analytics Team, Air Force Research Laboratory, and University of Dayton Research Institute

Features

Aurora Nears Full Deployment

The system surpassed the exascale barrier, demonstrated its world-class AI capabilities, and completed critical preparations for its release to the research community in 2025.

Aurora Performance Highlights

With Aurora fully assembled, early science team members began running and optimizing their applications to prepare the system for open access. Here are some early performance results on Aurora.

Linking Experimental Facilities and Leadership Computing

Argonne researchers are working to advance the DOE’s vision by integrating experimental facilities with ALCF computing resources.

ALCF Continues to Expand AI Testbed Systems Deployed for Open Science

By updating and expanding its testbed for AI accelerators, the ALCF enables users to harness leading-edge AI technologies for efficient and impactful scientific discovery.

Preparing a new generation of AI-ready researchers

Science Highlights

In 2023, scientists from across the world used ALCF supercomputing and AI resources to accelerate discovery and innovation across a wide range of research areas. The following science highlights detail some of the groundbreaking research campaigns carried out by ALCF users over the past year.

Insights

Argonne physicist Walter Hopkins discusses the importance of Aurora for extracting more information from particle physics experiments. Credit: Argonne National Laboratory

Argonne cosmologist Katrin Heitmann discusses how Aurora will help scientists search for dark energy and improve our understanding of the cosmos. Credit: Argonne National Laboratory

Argonne neuroscientist Bobby Kasthuri and computational scientist Nicola Ferrier discuss how Aurora and the upgraded APS will improve our understanding of the structure and function of the human brain. Credit: Argonne National Laboratory

  • 2024 Science Highlights
    • MProt-DPO: Breaking the ExaFLOPS Barrier for Multimodal Protein Design Workflows with Direct Preference Optimization Arvind Ramanathan, Argonne National Laboratory
    • Assessment of Turbulent Prandtl Number for Heavy Liquid Metal Flow in a Bare Rod Bundle Yiqi Yu, Emily Shemon, Argonne National Laboratory
    • Demonstrating Cross-Facility Data Processing at Scale with Laue Microdiffraction Michael Prince, Argonne National Laboratory
    • Efficient Algorithms for Monte Carlo Particle Transport on AI Accelerator Hardware John Tramm, Argonne National Laboratory
    • High-Fidelity Simulations of Gas Turbine Combustors for Sustainable Aviation Applications Muhsin Ameen, Sicong Wu, Argonne National Laboratory
    • First-Principles Simulation of Hypersonic Flight Maninder Grover, University of Dayton Research Institute
    • Three-Dimensional Shock Boundary Layer Interactions over Flexible Walls Johan Larsson, University of Maryland; Ivan Bermejo-Moreno, University of Southern California
    • Exascale Gyrokinetic Study of ITER Challenge on Power-Exhaust and ELM-Free Edge Choongseok Chang, Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory
    • Simulating the Cosmos for the Roman and Rubin Telescopes Katrin Heitmann, Argonne National Laboratory
    • State-of-the-Art High-Resolution 3D Simulations of Core-Collapse Supernovae Adam Burrows, Princeton University
